workflow.name: Telegram research assistant for academic papers using Gemini AI and Decodo
workflow.description:
## AI Research Assistant Using Gemini AI and Decodo

Sign up for Decodo [HERE](https://visit.decodo.com/discount) for Discount

This workflow transforms your Telegram bot into a smart academic research assistant powered by Gemini AI and Decodo. It analyzes queries, interprets URLs, scrapes scholarly data, and returns concise summaries of research papers directly in chat.

## Who‚Äôs it for?
For researchers, students, and AI enthusiasts who want to search and summarize academic content via Telegram using Google Scholar and arXiv.

## How it works
1. The Telegram bot captures text, voice, or image messages.
2. Gemini models interpret academic URLs and user intent.
3. Decodo extracts paper details like titles, abstracts, and publication info.
4. The AI agent summarizes results and delivers them as text or file (if too long).

## How to set up
- Add your Telegram bot credentials in the `Start Telegram Bot` node.
- Connect Google Gemini and Decodo API credentials.
- Replace `{{INPUT_SEARCH_URL_INSIGHTS}}` placeholder on `Research Summary Agent`'s system message with your search URL insights (or use the pinned example).
- Test by sending a text, image, or voice message to your bot.
- Activate the workflow to run in real-time.

parameters.text: =Sorry, i can only support text, photo, and voice message

options.systemMessage:
=## Overview
You are Research Summary Agent, a research assistant specialized in searching, analyzing, and summarizing academic papers based on user queries. Your role is to interpret the user's research intent, generate meaningful search queries, use provided academic sources and tools effectively, and return structured, concise, and useful summaries of relevant papers.  

## Tools
- Decodo ‚Äî A scraping utility capable of extracting titles, authors, abstracts, and publication details from academic web pages.  

## Objectives
1. Understand User Intent ‚Äî Analyze the user's message to determine the true research topic, context, and desired type of papers (e.g., comparative, conceptual, applied, or review).  
2. Extract Core Keywords ‚Äî Identify the essential and meaningful keywords or phrases that represent the main concept of the user‚Äôs request.  
   - Remove filler words (e.g., ‚Äúthe way of‚Äù, ‚Äústudy about‚Äù, ‚Äúpaper similar to‚Äù, ‚Äúresearch on‚Äù) and any quotes or formatting.  
   - If a specific paper title is mentioned, infer its *thematic keywords* (e.g., if ‚ÄúThe Way of the Artificial Intelligence‚Äù is mentioned, infer related keywords such as *artificial intelligence, cognitive systems, AI philosophy, AI methodology*).  
3. Plan Source Usage ‚Äî Review the available academic source URLs (e.g., Google Scholar, arXiv) and understand their parameters to determine the best way to perform relevant searches.  
4. Search & Retrieve ‚Äî For each source, construct a clear and semantically rich search query using the extracted keywords, ensuring broad yet relevant coverage rather than literal string matching.  
5. Use Tools Appropriately ‚Äî Use Decodo and other provided tools to scrape or retrieve paper metadata, abstracts, and links from the specified URLs.  
6. Filter & Rank Results ‚Äî Prioritize results that are:  
   - Topically relevant to the inferred research theme.  
   - Recent or influential (if available).  
   - Representative of the broader concept, not just identical titles.  
7. Summarize Findings ‚Äî Summarize each relevant paper in 2‚Äì3 lines, including title, year, authors, short abstract, and its relation to the topic.  
8. Respond Clearly ‚Äî Present all findings in a well-structured, easy-to-read format grouped by source (e.g., Google Scholar, arXiv).

## Rules
1. Only use the provided URLs and their described parameters when performing searches. Also, always search through all provided sources unless the user request for a specific source.  
2. Never use parameters across different sources ‚Äî each parameter must strictly apply to its corresponding source.  
3. Do not use the user‚Äôs message as a literal search phrase. Always convert it into a meaningful keyword-based query that reflects intent and core concepts.  
4. Never make assumptions about unavailable sources or invent results.  
5. Maintain factual accuracy, clarity, and neutrality in all summaries.  
6. When using Decodo, only extract data relevant to research context (titles, abstracts, authors, publication year, and URLs).  
7. Always cite the source (Google Scholar, arXiv, etc.) in the output.  
8. Each paper summary must be limited to 2‚Äì3 lines maximum, focusing on key insights, contribution, and relevance to the topic.  
9. Do not include unrelated metadata, extended commentary, or subjective interpretation.  
10. Prefer generalized or semantically equivalent keywords over verbatim text to ensure broader and more effective search coverage.

## Search Sources
The following list defines how each academic source and its parameters should be used for automated querying and analysis:

{{INPUT_SEARCH_URL_INSIGHTS}}

additionalFields.caption: =I've compiled the search result into a txt file because the content is too long for a single telegram message

parameters.content:
![Waha Johan](https://drive.google.com/thumbnail?id=1L2Ipo5Q41Uyw7KE_CJSnOPPArR7FXOFG&sz=w2000)
## AI Research Assistant Using Gemini AI and Decodo

Sign up for Decodo [HERE](https://visit.decodo.com/discount) for Discount

This workflow transforms your Telegram bot into a smart academic research assistant powered by Gemini AI and Decodo. It analyzes queries, interprets URLs, scrapes scholarly data, and returns concise summaries of research papers directly in chat.

## Who‚Äôs it for?
For researchers, students, and AI enthusiasts who want to search and summarize academic content via Telegram using Google Scholar and arXiv.

## How it works
1. The Telegram bot captures text, voice, or image messages.
2. Gemini models interpret academic URLs and user intent.
3. Decodo extracts paper details like titles, abstracts, and publication info.
4. The AI agent summarizes results and delivers them as text or file (if too long).

## How to set up
- Add your Telegram bot credentials in the `Start Telegram Bot` node.
- Connect Google Gemini and Decodo API credentials.
- Replace `{{INPUT_SEARCH_URL_INSIGHTS}}` placeholder on `Research Summary Agent`'s system message with your search URL insights (or use the pinned example).
- Test by sending a text, image, or voice message to your bot.
- Activate the workflow to run in real-time.

messageValues.message: =You are an AI URL Interpreter that specializes in analyzing academic search URLs. Your goal is to extract and explain all query parameters in a clear Markdown format so that an AI Research Agent can understand how to use them for research retrieval.

=Your task is to take a list of academic search URLs and analyze each one.

For each URL, you must:
1. Detect its source (e.g., Google Scholar, arXiv, Semantic Scholar, PubMed).
2. Combine all URLs from the same source into one section.
3. Extract and merge all unique parameters from those URLs (e.g., query terms, filters, search types, languages).
3. Ignore UI-related or tracking parameters.
5. Write one general note explaining what that platform‚Äôs search does and how parameters can modify behavior.

The output must be written in Markdown format, following this template for each URL:
### [Platform Name]
1. URL Examples:
   - [url_1]
   - [url_2]
2. Note: [summarized explanation of the platform and how parameters affect the search]
3. Parameters:
   - [parameter_name]: [meaning or function]
   - ...

=### Google Scholar
1. URL Examples:
   - https://scholar.google.com/scholar?q=artificial+intelligence&hl=en&as_sdt=0,5
   - https://scholar.google.com/scholar?as_ylo=2025&q=artificial+intelligence&hl=en&as_sdt=0,5
2. Note: Google Scholar is a search engine for scholarly articles, theses, and academic literature. These URLs perform searches for ‚Äúartificial intelligence‚Äù in English, including all scholarly articles and citations. Additional parameters like `as_ylo` allow filtering by publication year to find the most recent works.
3. Parameters:
   - q: The main search query (e.g., "artificial+intelligence").
   - hl: Interface language (e.g., "en" for English).
   - as_sdt: Search scope control. "0,5" includes all articles and citations.
   - as_ylo: Minimum publication year filter (e.g., "2025" to show recent works only).

### arXiv
1. URL Examples:
   - https://arxiv.org/search/?query=artificial+intelligence&searchtype=all&abstracts=show&order=-announced_date_first
   - https://arxiv.org/search/?query=artificial+intelligence&searchtype=all&source=header
2. Note: arXiv is an open-access repository for research preprints in fields such as computer science, physics, and mathematics. These URLs search for ‚Äúartificial intelligence‚Äù papers across all fields, optionally displaying abstracts and sorting by date. Parameters like `order` and `size` control sorting and number of results shown per page.
3. Parameters:
   - query: The main keyword being searched (e.g., "artificial+intelligence").
   - searchtype: Defines search scope ("all" searches across title, abstract, and authors).
   - abstracts: Controls whether abstracts are displayed ("show" = visible).
   - order: Sorting order ("-announced_date_first" = newest first).
   - size: Number of results displayed per page.

parameters.content:
## Search URL Insights
Use this workflow section to automatically generate clear explanation of academic search URLs (e.g., Google Scholar, arXiv, PubMed, etc.). It helps the `Research Summary Agent` understand how each platform‚Äôs query parameters work ‚Äî allowing it to construct smarter, semantically rich search queries for scraping and summarization.

## How to Use
1. Enter an array of academic search URLs you want to analyze on `Define Search URLs`.
2. Run the workflow to generate insight for corresponding URLs.
3. Copy the generated insights (or the pinned example) and paste it into the `{{INPUT_SEARCH_URL_INSIGHTS}}` placeholder inside the `Research Summary Agent`‚Äôs system message
### Create a Telegram bot using BotFather and paste its API key into n8n credentials
### Replace _{{INPUT_SEARCH_URL_INSIGHTS}}_ in the system message with your search URL insights (see to red sticky note)

Generate Search URL Insights.text:
### Google Scholar
1. URL Examples:
   - https://scholar.google.com/scholar?q=artificial+intelligence&hl=en&as_sdt=0,5
   - https://scholar.google.com/scholar?as_ylo=2025&q=artificial+intelligence&hl=en&as_sdt=0,5
2. Note: Google Scholar is a specialized search engine for scholarly literature, including peer-reviewed papers, theses, books, preprints, abstracts, and technical reports from various academic publishers, professional societies, online repositories, and universities. Parameters allow specifying the main search query, filtering by publication year, and controlling the scope of the search to find relevant academic resources.
3. Parameters:
   - q: The main search query (e.g., "artificial+intelligence").
   - hl: Interface language (e.g., "en" for English). While this primarily affects the user interface, it can sometimes influence the relevance of results in multi-lingual contexts.
   - as_sdt: Search scope control. "0,5" typically means "articles and citations," including all scholarly documents.
   - as_ylo: Minimum publication year filter (e.g., "2025" to show works published in or after that year).

### arXiv
1. URL Examples:
   - https://arxiv.org/search/?query=artificial+intelligence&searchtype=all&abstracts=show&order=-announced_date_first
   - https://arxiv.org/search/?query=artificial+intelligence&searchtype=all&source=header
2. Note: arXiv is an open-access repository of electronic preprints (e-prints) approved for posting after moderation, but not peer-reviewed. It covers fields such as physics, mathematics, computer science, quantitative biology, quantitative finance, statistics, electrical engineering and systems science, and economics. Parameters allow users to specify search terms, define the search scope (e.g., searching all fields, or specific fields like author or title), control display options like showing abstracts, and set the sorting order for results.
3. Parameters:
   - query: The main keyword(s) or phrase being searched (e.g., "artificial+intelligence").
   - searchtype: Defines the fields to search within (e.g., "all" searches across title, abstract, and authors).
   - abstracts: Controls whether abstracts are displayed in the search results ("show" makes them visible).
   - order: Specifies the sorting order of the results (e.g., "-announced_date_first" sorts by the newest papers first).

data.details:
The IF node can be used to implement binary conditional logic in your workflow. You can set up one-to-many conditions to evaluate each item of data being inputted into the node. That data will either evaluate to TRUE or FALSE and route out of the node accordingly.

This node has multiple types of conditions: Bool, String, Number, and Date & Time.
